header.title: ITV Good Morning Britain: Piers Morgan LASHES OUT at guests in SAS women row
header.subtitle: GOOD MORNING BRITAIN presenters Piers Morgan and Susanna Reid welcomed two former-SAS members to discuss the possibility of women joining the prestigious force, but things quickly became a little heated during the debate.
header.postText: Good Morning Britain presenters Piers Morgan and Susanna Reid discussed the viability of the SAS hiring female troopers.', 'And their guests, former SAS members Rusty Firmin and Phil Campion, were brought onto the show to discuss the topic, and things quickly got heated.', 'Piers began the debate by simply asking: “What is your problem with having women in the SAS?”', 'To which Rusty quickly replied: “It’s not a problem i’m just old school.', '“We have the best forces and we’ve taken a long time to get there.”', 'Later in the discussion Rusty added: “Male and female officers serving together is not a good idea - and it’s not all about passing a test by the way. It’s about the hardships they go through.”', 'Susanna jumped in to ask: “Are you worried about relationships?”', 'Leaving Rusty to admit: “Yes, and wives would be more worried than me.”', 'While Phil was not opposed to the notion of having women in the SAS, he did mention he would like to see “the whole package” from any recruit.', 'Itching for an answer Piers asked: “If it’s not about physical brute force what is it about any woman not being able to get through?”', 'He went on to ask them: “Is there a whiff of sexism from you two?”', 'Both of the guests furious denied the claim, saying: “No, no, not at all!”', 'Rusty then defended his views, explaining: “We’re talking about the British army here, not foreign armies.”', 'And when Piers asked: “Would you trust a woman you’re fighting alongside to cover your back?” Rusty bluntly responded: “No I would not.”', 'And viewers themselves were outraged by the idea as well, with one writing on Twitter: “We are saying its elite and women cant do it… YES WOMEN can… like anything it’s being given a chance, and having belief in the person #gmb.”', 'Another wrote: “#GMB respect for SAS. Yes to women being allowed a chance for selection.”', '“Women in the SAS, why not? This is about capability not sexuality. #GMB,” a third added.', 'Meanwhile some agreed with the SAS members, saying: “Women shouldn’t be in the SAS. If you don’t understand why then you probably don’t appreciate what the SAS do #GMB.”', 'With another agreeing: “Standard people on Twitter don’t know what they’re talking about again. Women should not be allowed to join the SAS #GMB.”', 'Good Morning Britain airs weekdays at 6am on ITV.

commentThread.commentText: The SAS train recruits to a specific standard of durabilty, intelligence and determination. Any woman meeting those standards would deserve a place - but 'watering down' the selection to allow women a greater chance of passing is simply lowering the odds of survival in a real-world combat environment - both for the woman and the team around her.
How about scrapping separate events in the Olympic games, and professional tennis etc., by just allowing gender neutral athletes to compete.

When they can carry the same amount of equipment  that the men do when on selection,  55 lbs that increases plus assult rifle food and water on the four week aptitude phase  that starts with five timed marches between 14 and 17 miles long over a ten day period that has the 15 mile Fan Dance that has to be completed in six hours where you have to show your ability to lead your section by just compass and map only again full equipped, That then ends with a forty mile forced march that has to be completed in 20 hours again full equipped.  Ignoring all the chaffing that comes with having a full Bergan on your back on the first timed march along with the blisters you get that both get worse on each march.Then they will have a chance. Then if they can be dropped into the Borneo jungle quite literally from 1,000 ft to lean combat training where they will get split up into groups of four where they after rely on each other as they learn how to survive in an hostile environment undetected by the enemy who are your own people hunting for you surviving fast flowing rivers as they are detected and they are escaping if they can survive all that and much more when on their probation period where they will at least once walk out from a high altitude aircraft 30000 ft above the ground with enough equipment to start world war three then I dont have any objection.But it has to exactly like the men do with not even an ounce taken from their packs.
